prior_works.title: Object-Centric Learning with Slot Attention
prior_works.relationship_sentence: REMA’s selective slot-based reconstruction directly builds on slot-attention’s ability to parse scenes into a small set of object slots, using reconstruction to induce object-centric factors without supervision.

prior_works.title: MONet: Unsupervised Scene Decomposition and Representation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The sequential attention masking and mixture-based reconstruction in MONet informed REMA’s strategy of selectively reconstructing major components to obtain disentangled object parts.

prior_works.title: Dynamic Routing Between Capsules
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Capsule networks’ emphasis on part–whole relationships and pose-aware routing inspired REMA’s focus on capturing and matching the topological relations among discovered components.

prior_works.title: Topological Autoencoders
prior_works.relationship_sentence: TopoAE introduced optimizing representation spaces to preserve topological structure, motivating REMA’s objective of enforcing topological homogeneity across instances/domains.

prior_works.title: Fused Gromov–Wasserstein Distances for Structured Domain Adaptation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: GW-based matching offered a principled way to align sets by their intra-set relational structure, directly informing REMA’s structure-preserving matching across slot components.

prior_works.title: Invariant Risk Minimization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: IRM’s environment-invariant predictors highlight the limits of pairwise invariance, motivating REMA’s move to higher-order, topology-level invariances for OOD robustness.

prior_works.title: Deep CORAL: Correlation Alignment for Deep Domain Adaptation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Deep CORAL’s pairwise second-order alignment exemplifies the statistical-invariance approaches REMA surpasses by matching component-level relational structure.

synthesis_narrative:
REMA’s core idea—learn object components via reconstruction and enforce their relational (topological) consistency to gain OOD robustness—sits at the intersection of object-centric representation learning, topological consistency, and structure-preserving matching. Object-centric methods such as MONet and Slot Attention established that reconstructive training with a limited set of slots and selective attention can disentangle scenes into meaningful parts without supervision; REMA adapts this recipe with a selective slot-based reconstruction module targeted at identifying major components that remain stable across domains. Capsule Networks provided a conceptual precedent for encoding part–whole relationships and pose, motivating REMA’s emphasis on the topology of component interactions rather than only their appearance.

To translate this intuition into a robust objective, REMA draws on topological regularization ideas from Topological Autoencoders, which argue that learning should preserve higher-order structure in representation spaces. Complementing this, Gromov–Wasserstein–style structure matching offers a practical mechanism to align sets of components by their intra-set relations, naturally handling permutation and cardinality issues while enforcing topological homogeneity across instances and domains.

Finally, domain generalization and OOD robustness methods like IRM and Deep CORAL crystallize the limitations of pairwise statistical invariance and environment-aligned predictors. By replacing pairwise feature alignment with reconstruction-driven component discovery and structure-aware matching, REMA directly addresses these shortcomings, yielding invariances at the level of object topology that transfer more reliably under distribution shift.
